content.text: C++ Classes and Objects
C++ Classes/Objects
C++ is an object-oriented programming language.

Everything in C++ is associated with classes and objects, along with its attributes and methods. For example: in real life, a car is an object . The car has attributes , such as weight and color, and methods , such as drive and brake.
content.html: Everything in C++ is associated with classes and objects, along with its attributes and methods. For example: in real life, a car is an object. The car has attributes, such as weight and color, and methods, such as drive and brake.

content.text: Attributes and methods are basically variables and functions that belongs to the class. These are often referred to as "class members".
content.html: Attributes and methods are basically variables and functions that belongs to the class. These are often referred to as "class members".

content.text: A class is a user-defined data type that we can use in our program, and it works as an object constructor, or a "blueprint" for creating objects.
content.html: A class is a user-defined data type that we can use in our program, and it works as an object constructor, or a "blueprint" for creating objects.

content.text: Create a Class
To create a class, use the class keyword:
content.html: To create a class, use the class keyword:

content.code_html:
class MyClass {       // The class
  public:             // Access specifier
    int myNum;        // Attribute (int variable)
    string myString;  // Attribute (string variable)
};

content.text: Example explained
Create an Object
In C++, an object is created from a class. We have already created the class named MyClass , so now we can use this to create objects.
content.html: In C++, an object is created from a class. We have already created the class named MyClass, so now we can use this to create objects.

content.text: To create an object of MyClass , specify the class name, followed by the object name.
content.html: To create an object of MyClass, specify the class name, followed by the object name.

content.text: To access the class attributes ( myNum and myString ), use the dot syntax ( . ) on the object:
content.html: To access the class attributes (myNum and myString), use the dot syntax (.) on the object:

content.code_html:
class MyClass {       // The class
  public:             // Access specifier
    int myNum;        // Attribute (int variable)
    string myString;  // Attribute (string variable)
};

int main() {
  MyClass myObj;  // Create an object of MyClass

  // Access attributes and set values
  myObj.myNum = 15; 
  myObj.myString = "Some text";

  // Print attribute values
  cout << myObj.myNum << "\n";
  cout << myObj.myString;
  return 0;
}

content.text: Multiple Objects
You can create multiple objects of one class:
content.html: You can create multiple objects of one class:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a Car class with some attributes

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a Car class with some attributes

content.code_html:
// Create a Car class with some attributes
class Car {
  public:
    string brand;   
    string model;
    int year;
};

int main() {
  // Create an object of Car
  Car carObj1;
  carObj1.brand = "BMW";
  carObj1.model = "X5";
  carObj1.year = 1999;

  // Create another object of Car
  Car carObj2;
  carObj2.brand = "Ford";
  carObj2.model = "Mustang";
  carObj2.year = 1969;

  // Print attribute values
  cout << carObj1.brand << " " << carObj1.model << " " << carObj1.year << "\n";
  cout << carObj2.brand << " " << carObj2.model << " " << carObj2.year << "\n";
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a Car class with some attributes

content.text: Challenge Task
Create a class called Book with the following attributes:
content.html: Create a class called Book with the following attributes:

content.text: Then create two objects of the class and print their attribute values.
content.html: Then create two objects of the class and print their attribute values.

content.code:
Matilda, Roald Dahl, 1988

The Giving Tree, Shel Silverstein, 1964
content.code_html:
Matilda, Roald Dahl, 1988
The Giving Tree, Shel Silverstein, 1964

#include <iostream>
#include <string>
using namespace std;

class Book {
  public:
    string title;
    string author;
    int year;
};

int main() {
  Book book1;
  book1.title = "Matilda";
  book1.author = "Roald Dahl";
  book1.year = 1988;

  Book book2;
  book2.title = "The Giving Tree";
  book2.author = "Shel Silverstein";
  book2.year = 1964;

  cout << book1.title << ", " << book1.author << ", " << book1.year << "\n";
  cout << book2.title << ", " << book2.author << ", " << book2.year;
  return 0;
}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the role of a class in C++?
content.html: What is the role of a class in C++?

metadata.question: What is the role of a class in C++?

options.text: To perform calculations within a program
To define a template or blueprint for creating objects
To act as an external library
